case_name: Not identifiable from the provided text

facts.text: Two appeals arise out of proceedings under section 34 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 to bring to tax Rs. 27,30,094 received by the appellant during the account year 1942-1943

anchor.surface_text: Venkatarama Aiyar, J. These two appeals arise out of proceedings taken under section 34 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, hereinafter referred to as the Act, to bring to tax a sum of Rs. 27,30,094 received by the appellant during the account year 1942-1943.

facts.text: Appellant is a public limited company incorporated in 1921 under the Gwalior Companies Act in the independent State of Gwalior

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a public limited companypany incorporated in 1921 under the provisions of the Gwalior Companies Act in what was then the independent State of Gwalior, and carries on business in the manufacture and sale of textiles.

facts.text: Appellant carries on business in manufacture and sale of textiles with registered office at Gwalior and is a non-resident company for purposes of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Its registered office is at Gwalior, and it is a number-resident companypany for the purposes of the Act. Its managing agents are Birla Brothers, Ltd. which is a private limited companypany registered in British India.

facts.text: Managing agents of appellant are Birla Brothers Ltd, a private limited company registered in British India

anchor.surface_text: Its managing agents are Birla Brothers, Ltd. which is a private limited companypany registered in British India. The point in dispute in these proceedings is whether sums of money received by the appellant during the account year 1942-1943

facts.text: Appellant received sums aggregating Rs. 27,30,094 during account year 1942-1943 which represent profits on forward contracts in cotton

anchor.surface_text: The point in dispute in these proceedings is whether sums of money received by the appellant during the account year 1942-1943 and aggregating to Rs. 27,30,094 are liable to be taxed under the Act.

facts.text: Appellant admits receiving Rs. 27,30,094 during 1942-1943 as profits from forward contracts in cotton

anchor.surface_text: The appellant admits that it received those monies during that period, and further that they represent profits made by it on certain forward companytracts in Jarilla companyton.

facts.text: Appellant contends contracts entered at Gwalior with brokers Lashkar Trading Company, Banwarilal Shivkumar and Meghraj Mundra

anchor.surface_text: But it companytends that those companytracts were entered into at Gwalior with three brokers, viz., Lashkar Trading Company, Banwarilal Shivkumar and Meghraj Mundra, that the agreements between the parties specifically provide that the goods are to be delivered and prices paid at Gwalior,

facts.text: Department contends contracts entered by managing agents with Jwaladutt Kishanprasad at Bombay and profits accrued in Bombay

anchor.surface_text: The Department, on the other hand, companytends that the companytracts which resulted in the profits of Rs. 27,30,094 were as a fact entered into by the managing agents of the appellant with firm of Jwaladutt Kishanprasad at Bombay, that those profits accrued in Bombay,

facts.text: Profits of Rs. 27,30,094 traceable to firm of Jwaladutt Kishanprasad

anchor.surface_text: and that they were therefore taxable under the Act. It is companymon ground that the sum of Rs. 27,30,094 received by the appellant as profits is in the ultimate analysis traceable to the firm of Jwaladutt Kishanprasad, and came from it.

facts.text: Appellant placed orders with three brokers in Gwalior who placed with J.R. Pillani Gwalior, branch of Jwaladutt Kishanprasad Bombay

anchor.surface_text: According to it, the companyrse of dealings relating to these transactions was as follows The appellant placed its orders for the sale or purchase of companyton with the three brokers mentioned above in Gwalior. They in their turn placed orders for the sale or purchase of the same quantity of goods with the firm of J. R. Pillani, Gwalior.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held by order dated March 23, 1948 that contracts entered by managing agents at Bombay and brokers were dummies

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer who investigated the matter held by his order dated March 23, 1948, that the forward companytracts in question had really been entered into by the managing agents of the appellant at Bombay, that the profits thereon had accrued at Bombay,

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO order on November 14, 1949

anchor.surface_text: and that the three brokers of Gwalior were mere dummies who had been put up to companyceal the true character of the transactions. This order was companyfirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal on November 14, 1949.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal remanded case on July 26, 1950 for further investigation

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took the matter in further appeal to the Appellate Tribunal which by its order dated July 26, 1950, remanded the case for further investigation of the true part played by the several intermediaries,

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner after fresh evidence held on August 17, 1951 that contracts made by G.D. Birla and R.D. Birla at Bombay with Jwaladutt Kishanprasad and broker contracts bogus

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this order, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner took fresh evidence, and examined as many as seven witnesses, and on a careful and detailed analysis of their evidence, he held in his report dated August 17, 1951, that the forward companytracts in question had been entered into with Jwaladutt Kishanprasad by G. D. Birla and R. D. Birla in person or by phone at Bombay,

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal affirmed AAC on February 28, 1952

anchor.surface_text: and that the companytract numberes with the three brokers were bogus transactions. On this report, the appeal came up for further hearing before the Appellate Tribunal, which by its order dated February 28, 1952, agreed with the companyclusions of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and affirmed its decision.

facts.text: Tribunal dismissed s.66(1) application on June 13, 1952

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied under section 66 1  of the Act for referring certain questions for the opinion of the companyrt, but the said application was dismissed by the Tribunal on June 13, 1952, on the ground that the points raised were pure questions of fact.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed s.66(2) application on August 6, 1952 by Chagla CJ and Bhagwati J

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied to the High Court of Bombay under section 66 2  of the Act to direct the Tribunal to refer certain questions to the companyrt, and that application was dismissed by Chagla, C.J., and Bhagwati, J., on August 6, 1952,

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 204 of 1954 preferred against High Court order on leave granted by Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: and against that order, Civil Appeal No. 204 of 1954 has been preferred on leave granted by this companyrt. By way of abundant caution, the appellant also applied for and obtained special leave to appeal against the order of the Tribunal dated February 28, 1952,

facts.text: Appeal No. 163 of 1958 against Tribunal order dated February 28, 1952 on special leave

anchor.surface_text: and that is Appeal No. 163 of 1958. Mr. Kolah, the learned companynsel for the appellant, stated that as the matter arising for decision in both the appeals is the same, he would address one argument with reference to both of them.

anchor.surface_text: The three brokers in whose names the companytracts stood were, having regard to their means, number likely to have been thought of for companytracts of the magnitude which we have. holdings.text: No question of law arises on the order of the Tribunal as the dispute regarding taxability depends on the place of the forward contracts, which is a pure question of fact.

anchor.surface_text: At the very outset, the question calls for an answer, does any question of law arise on the order of the Tirbunal ? It is only if it does, that the decision of the Tribunal will be open to consideration by the court under section 66 of the Act. Stating the same proposition in a different form, if that decision is one of fact turning on the appreciation of evidence, this court would not interfere with it in appeal under article 136 of the Constitution. Now, the point in dispute in these proceedings is whether the sum of Rs. 27,30,094 received by the appellant as profits in 1942-1943 is taxable under the Act, and that, in turn, depends on whether the forward contracts which resulted in these profits were made at Gwalior as contended by the appellant or at Bombay as held by the Tribunal. That would clearly be a question of fact, and the decision of the Tribunal thereon would not be liable to be challenged in these proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Taxability turns on factual question of place of contracts; Tribunal's finding on facts final unless erroneous in law.

holdings.text: The sum of Rs. 27,30,094 received by the non-resident appellant as profits is liable to tax under the Act as the profits accrued in British India (Bombay).

anchor.surface_text: Now, the point in dispute in these proceedings is whether the sum of Rs. 27,30,094 received by the appellant as profits in 1942-1943 is taxable under the Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-resident taxable only on income accruing in taxable territory; contracts entered and profits accrued at Bombay.

holdings.text: The forward contracts resulting in the profits were entered into at Bombay, not at Gwalior.

anchor.surface_text: and that, in turn, depends on whether the forward contracts which resulted in these profits were made at Gwalior as contended by the appellant or at Bombay as held by the Tribunal. That would clearly be a question of fact, and the decision of the Tribunal thereon would not be liable to be challenged in these proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal finding affirmed based on evidence that managing agents contracted directly with Jwaladutt Kishanprasad at Bombay; Gwalior brokers interposed as dummies.

holdings.text: The Tribunal's finding of fact that the contracts were made at Bombay is not erroneous in law as it is supported by evidence and not perverse.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant does not dispute this position, but he contends that a finding of the Tribunal even on a question of fact would be erroneous in law,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Meenakshi Mills Ltd. propositions: interference only if no evidence or perverse; here evidence exists and reasonable.

holdings.text: The Tribunal's finding is supported by direct testimony of J.R. Pillani and corroborated by circumstantial evidence including accounts and brokers' lack of capacity.

anchor.surface_text: Approaching the question from this standpoint, we pose the question, what is the evidence in support of the findings of the Tribunal that the forward contracts which resulted in the profits of Rs. 27,30,094 were made in Bombay and not in Gwalior ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pillani testified Birlas contracted at Bombay; corroborated by payment flows, blanks in accounts filled later, brokers' dummy status (no means, no prior business, cash dealings).

holdings.text: The contracts with the three Gwalior brokers were sham transactions and not genuine.

anchor.surface_text: Every person is entitled so to arrange his affairs as to avoid taxation but the arrangement must be real and genuine and not a sham or make-believe, and the question now under consideration is whether the contracts with the brokers were genuine.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Brokers lacked means for large deals, no cotton futures experience, no bank accounts, cash payments, poor records; interposed to conceal Bombay contracts.

holdings.text: A taxpayer may arrange affairs to avoid tax provided the arrangement is real and genuine, not sham or make-believe.

anchor.surface_text: Every person is entitled so to arrange his affairs as to avoid taxation but the arrangement must be real and genuine and not a sham or make-believe, and the question now under consideration is whether the contracts with the brokers were genuine.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle applied to facts; appellant's arrangement sham as brokers dummies to conceal taxable accrual in Bombay.

holdings.text: There is no misdirection or non-direction in the Tribunal's order; its finding is not open to attack under Article 136.

anchor.surface_text: We have considered all the contentions urged on behalf of the appellant at some length. We would like to make it clear that we are not sitting here as a court of appeal on facts. We have examined the record only with a view to see whether there is any misdirection or non-direction,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Record examined; contentions rejected; evidence sufficient, no procedural irregularity.

precedents.citation: Meenakshi Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax

anchor.surface_text: Meenakshi Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax, and the law was thus stated The position that emerges on the authorities may thus be summed up When the point for determination is a pure question of law such as construction of a statute or document of title, the decision of the Tribunal is open to reference to the court under section 66(1). When the point for determination is a mixed question of law and fact, while the finding of the Tribunal on the facts found is final in decision as to the legal effect of that finding is a question of law which can be reviewed by the court. A finding on a question of fact is open to attack under section 66(1) as erroneous in law when there is noevidence to support or if it is perverse. When the finding is one of fact, the fact that it is itself an inference from other basic facts will not alter its character as one of facts.

precedents.case_name: Meenakshi Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: A finding of the Tribunal on a question of fact is erroneous in law if there is no evidence to support it or if it is perverse
precedents.cited_holding: The position that emerges on the authorities may thus be summed up [detailed propositions on pure question of law, mixed question of law and fact, no evidence or perverse finding, inference from facts]

anchor.surface_text: At the very outset, the question calls for an answer, does any question of law arise on the order of the Tirbunal ? It is only if it does, that the decision of the Tribunal will be open to consideration by the court under section 66 of the Act. Stating the same proposition in a different form, if that decision is one of fact turning on the appreciation of evidence, this court would not interfere with it in appeal under article 136 of the Constitution. Now, the point in dispute in these proceedings is whether the sum of Rs. 27,30,094 received by the appellant as profits in 1942-1943 is taxable under the Act, and that, in turn, depends on whether the forward contracts which resulted in these profits were made at Gwalior as contended by the appellant or at Bombay as held by the Tribunal. That would clearly be a question of fact, and the decision of the Tribunal thereon would not be liable to be challenged in these proceedings.
In the result, the appeals fail, and are dismissed. The respondent will get its costs in Civil Appeal No. 204 of 1954. The parties will bear their own costs in
